awd_titl_txt: CRII: NeTS: Modeling and Analysis of Green Mobile Crowd Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
Mobile crowd sensing (MCS) arises as a new sensing paradigm based on the power of the crowd together with the ever-increasing sensing capabilities of various mobile devices. As carrying out sensing tasks can deplete the energy of battery-powered mobile devices quickly, this concern largely affects the wide deployment of MCS. Therefore, how to enhance the energy efficiency in MCS is an imperative and challenging task. Inspired by recent advances in wireless networking and energy harvesting techniques, the proposed research aims to develop joint sensing task computation and communication framework to achieve green MCS for various sensing tasks. The research project and activities have significant potential to better support newly emerging MCS applications such as healthcare, environment monitoring, traffic monitoring, social behavior monitoring, etc. The research results are expected to inspire other theoretical and systematic studies to contribute to the networking design and energy management aspects of developing energy-efficient MCS. The project plans to engage female and under-represented minority students in the research activities. The results of the project will be disseminated through publications and talks.

This project has an exciting two-year research plan focusing on fundamental challenges associated with modeling and analyzing green MCS. Observing that the energy consumed in task processing and its distribution correlates to each other, a unified framework to jointly model the energy consumption in computation and communication is proposed to strike a balance between the two to achieve energy efficiency. As renewable energy has emerged as a feasible alternative to the traditional energy sources, it is incorporated in the sensing crowd so as to decrease the on-grid energy demand from sensing devices. Dynamic energy optimization problems are then investigated to minimize energy expenditure in supporting performance-guaranteed sensing tasks, by comprehensively considering time-varying computing resource allocation, renewable energy supply, and wireless channel conditions. Moreover, some sensing devices are envisioned to be capable of transferring extra harvested renewable energy to others nearby, so as to fully explore the vacant energy and computation resources in MCS. Finally, in order to stimulate mobile devices to join MCS, incentive mechanisms and heterogeneous auction markets are developed.

por.por_cntn:
Mobile crowd sensing (MCS) arises as a new sensing paradigm based on the power of the crowd jointly with the sensing capabilities of various mobile devices. By fusing and analyzing the multi-dimensional sensing results collected by ubiquitous mobile terminals, it is possible to facilitate the development of health caring, environment monitoring, traffic monitoring, social behavior monitoring, etc. Although with all these promising visions, the wide deployment of MCS is largely hindered by its energy issues. Carrying out MCS tasks can deplete the mobile terminal's battery quickly. This project aims to achieve energy-efficient MCS by developing a unified framework that jointly optimizes the energy consumption for wireless transmissions and task execution. Under this framework, we further examined the energy efficiency brought by recent green energy techniques. We developed a set of technologies and made the following contributions.

First, we presented a cross-layer optimization framework for energy-efficient MCS. We jointly considered computing resource management, routing, and link scheduling to achieve overall energy efficiency among all MCS nodes. We developed quantitative models for characterizing the dynamic energy consumption of wireless communications and computation of MCS tasks. These models formulate MCS task offloading into stochastic optimizations with intertwined cross-domain constraints. We further developed various online methods for task allocation and data transmissions among MCS nodes with minimum energy consumption overhead.

Second, we modeled interactions among MCS nodes. Executing MCS sensing tasks could be energy-consuming for mobile terminals. We investigated how to motivate the crowd to participate in MCS and compensate for their energy cost. Game theories and incentive design have been adopted to characterize the interactions among different entities. Critical economic properties, such as equilibrium, truthfulness, and individual rationality, have also been analyzed.

Third, we have implemented the above MCS system designs over practical mobile system testbeds, and conducted various real experiments to demonstrate their applicability in real-world MCS scenarios. We have opensourced part of our code, including the MCS system implementation and proposed algorithms/mechanisms.

Many of the research results have been integrated with the education curricula at the University of Nevada Reno and the University of Texas at Arlington. The project has supported two Ph.D. students working on their dissertations. The research outcome has also been used to involve two undergraduate students in this research.
